description: Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.
name: GENERAL CHEMISTRY II

values.comments:
This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

Students agreed that the course material was for the most part was “dry.” Students found that they “learned quite a bit about chemistry” from this class.  Overall, students felt that they walked away from the course with a much deeper understanding of chemistry, though the class did require a lot of work.

Students agreed that Professor Topp was “extremely knowledgeable” and “truly concerned and dedicated to the well-being of his students.”  Additionally, students felt that he was “very accessible” outside of the classroom.  However, students overwhelmingly felt that “he is not very good as a lecturer.”  Students noted that he read off slides instead of working through the material in an engaging manner.  Some students even felt that Professor Topp was “out of touch with the needs of the class.”  His exams in particular were described as “very long and difficult.”  This was most likely due to the fact that Professor Topp tested conceptual knowledge rather than only having math problem. 

Students recommended this course for majors, but found it very difficult. Some students complained that the course “assumed you have some chemistry background” beyond the CHEM 101 prerequisite.

This course is a continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

  Students agreed that the course material was for the most part was “dry.” Students found that they “learned quite a bit about chemistry” from this class.  Overall, students felt that they walked away from the course with a much deeper understanding of chemistry, though the class did require a lot of work.

Students had overwhelmingly positive comments about Professor Schelter.  One student described him as “the best science teacher I’ve had in my four semesters here.”  Another student said he was “very engaging” and explained the material extremely thoroughly.   Students recommended Professor Schelter “for any science class he teaches.”  

Students recommended this course for majors, but still found it very difficult. Some students complained that the course “assumed you have some chemistry background” beyond the CHEM 101 prerequisite. Some students felt that his exams were “very difficult” and did not reflect class material or practice exams very well.

Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.

       Students said that the class was “thought provoking” and “very challenging.” Multiple professors taught the course. 

	Students generally praised Professor Pietrovito’s class notes posted online, calling them “great” and “detailed and thorough.” Many thought that, while a generally good professor, Professor Pietrovito was often difficult to pay attention to for extended periods of time in class. However, many students praised him for his teaching abilities; clarity when describing the material; and his willingness to answer questions. 

This section of the course was specified as engineering chemistry. Because of this, one student noted that it was “much more difficult” than the other sections of the course since it favored those who already had a lot of knowledge of the material. One student remarked that the course required too much effort.  This course fulfilled the Physical World Sector. The prerequisite for this course was CHEM 101.

Continuation of Chemistry 101.  The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms.  It includes special topics in chemistry.

	This course was generally regarded as a good experience. Although the readings and lectures were found to be mildly dull, students found the course to be “challenging but interesting.” Students liked the real world applications presented in the lectures.

	Students uniformly praised Professor Phillips. She was repeatedly described as “nice,” “friendly,” “a great instructor,” and “always available for questions.” Professor Phillips conveyed the information in such a way that students found the material “easily understandable” and “very easy.” Several students said that Professor Phillips was “the best science professor I have had at Penn so far.” Many of the students said they would recommend Professor Phillips to anyone taking the course.

This course was generally regarded as fairly easy for this type of course, mostly as a result of the Professor’s teaching. The tests were widely regarded as fair. One student described the amount of material as “not overwhelming.” This course fulfilled the Physical World Sector. The prerequisite for this course was CHEM 101.

Continuation of Chemistry 101. The second term stresses the thermodynamic approach to chemical reactions, electrochemical processes, and reaction rates and mechanisms. It includes special topics in chemistry.
	Overall, students found this class to be extremely difficult, but a rewarding experience. Students said that the course resulted in them committing more to memory and learning more about chemistry than they ever had before. Many students thought that the lectures were too long.
	Professor Pietrovito was described by the majority of the students in this course as a very difficult professor, but one who was invested in the students’ success and understanding of the material. Professor Pietrovito was described as being “very available,” “very helpful,” and “dedicated” repeatedly by the students. Many also said that Professor Pietrovito cared a lot about his students and always offered extra time for help with the material, giving the students “plenty of opportunities to succeed.” Several students said that Professor Pietrovito made the material more difficult than it needed to be, but said that it paid off in their understanding of the material in the long-run.
	Students, overall, called this class and the exams very difficult. A lot of time was required because the tests required attention to tiny details as opposed to students’ general knowledge of the subject in addition to thinking about the questions rather than pure memorization. This course fulfilled the Physical World Sector. The prerequisite for this course was CHEM 101.
